Package gov.sandia.gmp.util.numerical.polygon

Class Polygon

java.lang.Object
gov.sandia.gmp.util.numerical.polygon.Polygon
All Implemented Interfaces:
Cloneable, Callable<Polygon>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Polygon3D
public class Polygon extends Object implements Cloneable, Callable<Polygon>
An ordered list of points on the surface of a unit sphere that define a closed polygon. Polygons have the ability to test whether or not an arbitrary test point on the sphere is inside or outside the polygon. When a polygon is constructed from a list of points, the side of the polygon that is deemed to be 'inside' is ambiguous. The user could intend that the smaller of the polygons be 'inside' or that the smaller polygon be 'outside'. With one exception, all of the polygon constuctors in this class assume that the smaller polygon is 'inside'. The exception is the constructor that creates a polygon from a center point and a radius. In that case, if the radius is > PI/2, then the larger polygon is deemed to be 'inside'. If the user wants the larger polygon to be 'inside', they can call method invert(), which will switch the polygons. The concept of 'inside' and 'outside' is implemented by having a reference point which is specified to be either inside or outside the polygon. Users can specify these values by calling setReferencePoint().

A convenient mechanism for generating polygons is to use Google Earth. It has the ability to interactively generate polygons and store them in kmz or kml files. Polygon has facilities to read and write kmz and kml files. Polygon can also read and write polygons to an ascii file. An advantage of the ascii file format is that the position of the reference point and whether the reference point is inside or outside the polygon are stored in the file and therefore can be manipulated by users. For example, if a user wishes to generate a polygon that is larger than a hemisphere, they could define the polygon boundary points with Google Earth but the resulting polygon would be inverted (the inside would be outside and the outside would be inside). They could use Polygon to write the polygon to an ascii file,and manually edit the file to modify the reference point definition.

A test point that is located very close to a polygon boundary is deemed to be 'inside' the polygon. This means that if two adjacent, non-overlapping polygons share a boundary point or a boundary edge, a test point near that point or edge will be deemed to be 'inside' both polygons. In this context two points are 'very close' if they are separated by less than 1e-7 radians or 5.7e-6 degrees. For a sphere with the radius of the Earth (6371 km), this corresponds to a linear distance of about 60 cm.

  • Field Details

    • edges

      protected ArrayList<GreatCircle> edges
      A GreatCircle object for each edge of the polygon.

    • referencePoint

      protected double[] referencePoint
      A point on the surface of the unit sphere that is used as a reference point. The status of this point relative to the polygon is known, i.e., it is known if this point is inside or outside the polygon.

    • referenceIn

      protected boolean referenceIn
      true if the referencePoint is inside the polygon.

    • area

      protected double area
      The area of the polygon, assuming a unit sphere. Area will range from zero to 4*PI. Lazy evaluation is used. Area is computed the first time the area is requested.

    • TOLERANCE

      protected static final double TOLERANCE
      Tolerance value in radians used when comparing locations of two points.
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • global

      protected boolean global
      If global is true this polygon encompasses the entire Earth and method contains() will always return the value of referenceIn.

    • lonFirst

      protected boolean lonFirst
      When reading/writing lat,lon data, should order be lat,lon or lon,lat.

    • attachment

      public Object attachment
      Some unspecified information that applications can attach to this polygon. This information is not processed in anyway by Polygon.

    • taskId

      protected int taskId

    • taskPointMap

      protected Map<double[],​Boolean> taskPointMap

    • taskPoints

      protected List<double[]> taskPoints

    • taskContained

      protected List<Boolean> taskContained

    • polygonFile

      protected File polygonFile

    • name

      protected String name
      Name of this polygon. If this polygon is loaded from a file, the name defaults to the name of the file without the extension.

      public Polygon​(File file) throws IOException
      Load a Polygon from a File. See section "Polygons" in the GeoTess User's Manual which can be found at http://www.sandia.gov/geotess/assets/documents/GeoTessUsersManual.pdf
      Parameters:

    • Polygon

      public Polygon​(boolean global)
      Create a global polygon. Method constains(x) will always return the value of global that is specified in this constructor.
      Parameters:
      global - boolean

    • Polygon

      public Polygon​(List<double[]> points) throws IOException
      Constructor that accepts a list of unit vectors that define the polygon. The polygon will be closed, i.e., if the first point and last point are not coincident then an edge will be created between them.

      The referencePoint will be the anti-pode of the normalized vector sum of the supplied points and will be deemed to be 'outside' the polygon.

      Parameters:
      points - Collection
      Throws:
      PolygonException
      IOException

    • Polygon

      public Polygon​(double[][] points) throws IOException
      Constructor that accepts a list of unit vectors that define the polygon. The polygon will be closed, i.e., if the first point and last point are not coincident then an edge will be created between them.
      Parameters:
      points - Collection
      Throws:
      PolygonException
      IOException

    • Polygon

      public Polygon​(double[] center, double radius, int nEdges) throws IOException
      Constructor that builds a circular polygon of a specified horizontal radius centered on position center.

      The referencePoint will be the anti-pode of the normalized vector sum of the supplied points and will be be deemed to be 'outside' the polygon.

      Parameters:
      center - unit vectors
      radius - double angular radius of the polygon, in radians.
      nEdges - int
      Throws:
      PolygonException
      IOException

    • write

      public void write​(File fileName) throws IOException
      Write the current polygon to a file. If the file extension is 'vtk' then the file is written in vtk format. If the file extension is 'kml' or 'kmz' the file is written in a format compatible with Google Earth. Otherwise the file is written in ascii format with boundary points written in lat-lon order.
      Parameters:
      fileName - name of file to receive the polygon
      Throws:
      IOException

    • getPolygonFile

      public File getPolygonFile()
      Returns the current polygon file setting (null if the polygon was never set from a standard file.
      Returns:
      The current polygon file setting.

    • write

      protected void write​(BufferedWriter output, String latLon) throws IOException
      Write the current polygon to a file in ascii format.
      Parameters:
      fileName - name of file to receive the polygon
      latLon - if this String starts with 'lon' the polygon boundary points will be written in lon-lat order otherwise they will be written in lat-lon order.
      Throws:
      IOException

    • invert

      public void invert()
      Invert the current polygon. What used to be in will be out and what used to be out will be in.

    • getArea

      public double getArea()
      Retrieve the area of this polygon. This is the unitless area (radians squared). To convert to km^2, multiply the result by R^2 where R is the radius of the sphere. The range is zero to 4*PI.
      Returns:

    • toString

      public String toString​(boolean repeatFirstPoint, boolean longitudeFirst, double minLongitude)
      Returns a String containing all the points that define the polygon with one lon, lat pair per record. lats and lons are in degrees.

      If longitudeFirst is true, points are listed as lon, lat. If false, order is lat, lon.

      Longitudes will be adjusted so that they fall in the range minLongitude to (minLongitude+360).

      Parameters:
      repeatFirstPoint -
      longitudeFirst - boolean
      minLongitude - double
      Returns:
      String

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Returns a String containing all the points that define the polygon with one lon, lat pair per record. lats and lons are in degrees. Longitudes range from -180 to 180 degrees.
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      String

    • contains

      public ArrayList<Boolean> contains​(List<double[]> points, int nProcessors) throws IOException
      Determine if a list of unit vectors is contained within this polygon. Concurrency is used to process batches of points in parallel.
      Parameters:
      points - list of points to evaluate
      nProcessors - number of processors to use in concurrent mode. If nProcessors < 2, points are evaluated in sequential mode.
      Returns:
      ArrayList of length equal to input points.
      Throws:
      IOException

    • contains

      public HashMap<double[],​Boolean> contains​(Set<double[]> points, int nProcessors) throws IOException
      Determine if a set of unit vectors is contained within this polygon. Concurrency is used to process batches of points in parallel.
      Parameters:
      points - set of points to evaluate
      nProcessors - number of processors to use in concurrent mode. If nProcessors < 2, points are evaluated in sequential mode.
      Returns:
      HashMap of length equal to input points.
      Throws:
      IOException

    • contains

      public void contains​(Map<double[],​Boolean> points, int nProcessors) throws IOException
      Determine if a set of unit vectors is contained within this polygon. Concurrency is used to process batches of points in parallel.
      Parameters:
      points - map from unit vector to boolean containing points to evaluate. Only points where getValue() == null are evaluated. If a point has getValue() = true or false, it is assumed that the point has already been evaluated and it is not evaluated again.
      nProcessors - number of processors to use in concurrent mode. If nProcessors < 2, points are evaluated in sequential mode.
      Throws:
      IOException
